In medieval times, illuminated manuscripts were considered luxury items created for wealthy patrons, such as monasteries, nobles, and the church. The costly materials and the labor-intensive techniques used in their production were intended to create visually striking works of art that conveyed both religious and secular messages. Gold and silver leaf were often used to highlight certain details, such as initial letters or borders, and to convey the preciousness and sacredness of the text, emphasizing the spiritual importance of the content. Thus, the use of gold and silver leaf was not necessarily for practical reasons or to save money, but rather to enhance the artistic beauty and symbolic value of the manuscript.
